3 but is actually f-stop 8

6 as advertised by Sony so the equivalent f-stop is 3
It is the actual dimensions of the aperture not "f-stop" that largely determines depth of focus
Photographers pay huge amounts of money for lenses that have as wide an aperture as possible
However photographers covet a shallow depth of field for beautiful portraits, close-ups and artistic control over the image
having most of the picture in focus is desirable
For pictures of landscapes, mountains and many other types of scenes
If you have a smaller opening more of the picture is in focus
less of the picture is in focus
The opening size controls not only how much light can pass through the lens in a given amount of time, but also the depth of focus or field
The numbers on the two lenses above are the same, so one would assume that the openings would be the same size, but this is not the case
This is referring to the aperture which is how wide the blades that control how much light passes through the camera can open
3" which on both lenses is referring to the maximum "f-stop" for the lens at full wide angle and full zoom
The numbers that people have a harder time with are the "3,5-6,3" and the "3
and they are, but of course at this time they still cannot match the performance of a much larger sensor
Small sensors must be much more sensitive than the larger sensors
I think that it is fairly obvious to everyone that a tiny sensor is going to be working with a lot less light
There are excellent articles discussing this if you search for "Full Frame Equivalence" in a search engine
That is one of the primary reasons why in this time of miniaturized everything you still see photographers running around with giant cameras with massively large lenses
A narrow depth of field is one of the primary tools that photographers use to create beautiful artistic photos
This obviously helps with their low light capabilities, but even more importantly from an artistic perspective
Cameras with larger sensors take larger lenses that have larger apertures and they can collect much more light
A camera with a small sensor currently cannot do everything that a camera with a large sensor can do
Also the digital trickery that the tiny computer inside the camera is able to perform to get the most out of the sensor is quite amazing as well
it is obviously much more efficient with the smaller amount of light it is sampling than larger sensors are
